div.p: Arquivo Histórico do Museu Bocage, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon.

It was with feelings of much delight, dear Professor Bocage, that I learnt of the generous consideration of His Majesty your gracious Souvereign having elevated me to so high a rank in the Royal Order of Christus,
See Luis I, King of Portugal to M, 28 April 1887 (in this edition as 87-04-28a). a distinction which I shall regard as one of my greatest rewards of such scientific labours as I endeavoured to carry out during nearly half a century. I will do all I can to show myself grateful for this act of royal grace from your Kingdom, and will also keep in thankful remembrance the obligations, under which you have placed me yourself. — So soon as the Royal Patent arrives I will write a full letter of gratitude to His Excellency, the Minister of foreign affairs.
Letter not found. Meanwhile you may have an opportunity to express my grateful homage to his Majesty.

It so occurred, that this week I was able to acquire some birds from North-East Australia, which with some marsupials from the south and some saurians will be dispatches to my London Agents, Mess. Watson and Scull (Lower Thames-Street) London, with a request, to forward this collection to your museum. I will at the same time send a number of rare Australian plants in dried specimens to the excellent Count Ficalho.

A volume of "Myoprorinous plants"
B86.08.05. and the decades of the Iconography of Australian Acacias
B87.13.04 (B88.13.04, the final five Decades, was not published until mid-to-late 1888). The promised volumes, assuming they were sent, would appear to have been personal gifts from M; no record has been found in the official distribution lists of the Public Library for 1887 or 1888 of copies of these works having been sent to the Portuguese Royal Library (Victoria, Parliamentary papers nos 24 (published 1888) and 59 (1889)). will (ornamentally bound) be soon sent to His Maj. Library.
